name: 5,7,7-trimethyl-4-(1-methylethyl)-3,6-dioxabicyclo[3.2.2]nonan-2-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2964

name: 5,7,7-trimethyl-4-(1-methylethyl)-3,6-dioxabicyclo[3.2.2]nonan-2-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2964
Reason: The basic unit of cyclohexane has a melting point of approximately 6.5°C. The presence of oxygen atoms in the form of ether linkages (–O–) generally increases the polarity which would typically increase the melting point due to stronger dipole-dipole interactions. However, the significant steric hindrance caused by the trimethyl groups and the isopropyl group may somewhat disrupt the crystal lattice, reducing the melting point increase. The carbonyl group (C=O) will contribute to an increase in the melting point through potential hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions. The bicyclic structure could also result in a higher melting point owing to the more rigid structure. The combined effect of these functional groups on the melting point needs to be considered quantitatively. We estimate these effects as follows: ether linkages: +20°C each, trimethyl and isopropyl groups: -5°C each due to steric hindrance, carbonyl group: +40°C, and the bicyclic structure: +10°C. There are two ether linkages, one carbonyl group, three trimethyl groups and one isopropyl group. Therefore, the total predicted quantitative effect on the melting point (taking into account the basic cyclohexane unit) would be: 6.5 (cyclohexane) + 2 * 20 (ether linkages) + 40 (carbonyl group) + 10 (bicyclic structure) - 3 * 5 (trimethyl groups) - 5 (isopropyl group) = 6.5 + 40 + 40 + 10 - 15 - 5 = 76.5°C

name: 5,7,7-trimethyl-4-(1-methylethyl)-3,6-dioxabicyclo[3.2.2]nonan-2-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2964
Reason: The basic unit of cyclohexane has a melting point of approximately 6.5°C. The presence of oxygen atoms in the form of ether linkages (–O–) generally increases the polarity, which typically raises the melting point due to stronger dipole-dipole interactions. Adding two ether linkages might increase the melting point by around +20°C each. The carbonyl group (C=O) also contributes to the increase through potential hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, estimated to be around +50°C. The three trimethyl groups and the isopropyl group add steric hindrance and bulk, which might decrease the melting point collectively by about -15°C due to disrupted crystal packing. The bicyclic structure introduces rigidity, which restricts molecular motion and can increase the melting point by around +30°C. Factoring these groups into the base value for cyclohexane provides the following summation: 6.5 (cyclohexane) + 2 * 20 (ether linkages) + 50 (carbonyl group) + 30 (bicyclic structure) - 15 (steric hindrance) = 6.5 + 40 + 50 + 30 - 15 = 111.5°C
